Award.AwardTitle: SusChem: IUPAC: The development of multi-functional catalysts to replace Pt for fuel oxidation reactions in low temperature fuel cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Rongrong Chen of Indianapolis University examines the development of multi-functional catalysts to replace platinum (Pt) in low temperature fuel oxidation reactions. Among the various alternative systems for energy production, fuel cells are particularly attractive because they allow clean and efficient conversion of chemical energy into electricity. Currently, the most active catalysts for the oxidation of fuels such as hydrogen, methanol and ethanol in fuel cells are Pt and Pt-based materials, which are too expensive for affordable clean energy production. This research project focuses on catalysts based on cheaper materials for fuel oxidation reactions in fuel cells. By combining electrochemical measurements, in-situ spectroscopic characterization, density functional theory simulations and fuel cell testing, the collaborative team studies reaction mechanisms of hydrogen, methanol and ethanol oxidation reactions (HORs, MORs and EORs, respectively) on various catalysts in both acid and alkaline media. New multi-functional catalysts based on low cost materials (such as palladium, nickel and other more earth abundant elements) with comparable reactivities to platinum-based catalysts are designed and characterized.

This project is performed in collaboration with Professor Hebe de las Mercedes in Brazil and Professor Shi-Gang Sun in China. Together, these groups combine their separate areas of expertise to examine less expensive and more sustainable fuel cell catalysts. Other broader impacts of this work include the training of postdoctoral fellows and graduate students and an international exchange of ideas and expertise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The environmentally friendly generation of energy has brought new scientific and technological challenges. Among the alternative systems for energy production, fuel cells are particularly attractive because they allow clean and efficient conversion of chemical energy into electricity. Currently, the most active catalyst for the oxidation of fuels such as hydrogen, methanol, and ethanol in fuel cells are Pt and Pt-based materials, which are too costly for affordable clean energy production. The development of catalysts based on cheaper materials for fuel oxidation reactions in fuel cells is needed. This research aims to develop novel multi-functional catalysts to replace Pt for fuel oxidation reactions in fuel cells through collaborative efforts by electrochemists from the United States, Brazil, and China. Specifically, combining electrochemical measurements, in-situ spectroscopy characterizations, and fuel cell testing, the joint team focused on studying reaction mechanisms of methanol and ethanol oxidation reactions (MORs and EORs) on various catalysts in alkaline media. Through understanding how surface and electronic structures of various catalysts affect the reaction kinetics of MORs and EORs in alkaline media, new multi-functional catalysts based on low cost materials (such as Pd) with better MORs and EORs activity to Pt-based catalysts were designed and characterized. Notably, alloying Pd with transition metals (such as Ru, Pb or Cu) were found to induce structural changes that alter the electronic characteristics of Pd surface active sites and the availability of oxygenated species on the catalyst surface needed to oxidize alcohol and its fragments. The effects of electronic properties on reactivity were also investigated by varying metal-support interactions. These new understandings of alcohol oxidation reaction mechanisms on Pt-based and Pd-based catalysts are critical to guild designs of robust catalysts for fuel oxidation in fuel cells and a promising means to produce eco-friendly energy.
